awd_titl_txt: Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Multimode Optical Pulse Propagation: Route to High-Performance Ultrafast Lasers
awd_abstract_narration:
Lasers that produce very short flashes of light (billionths of millionths of seconds in duration) can be used to observe very fast processes in nature, such as the motion of molecules or electrons.  They do this in much the same way a strobe light can freeze motion on much longer time scales. In addition, such flashes of light can be used in applications such as cutting industrial materials and precise surgery.
Such a laser can be made of optical fiber, which is attractive because the light is contained inside the fiber. In fibers used for this purpose to date, the core of the fiber is very small (a few millionths of a meter) and only a single pattern of the light propagates in the fiber. This pattern is what most people associate with a laser beam: a small spot that is brightest in its center. 
If the core of the fiber is made larger, other patterns can propagate. All of the allowed patterns overlap, so the beam that comes out is a complicated mix of them. Lasers based on multiple patterns can theoretically reach much higher powers, which are needed for applications, but the patterns must be controlled. 
In the last two years researchers have learned how to lock together multiple beam patterns in fiber lasers.  Groups from Cornell University and the University of Central Florida will work to make lasers and other sources of short light pulses based on fibers that support many overlapping beam patterns. Instruments with new capabilities, such as much higher powers, will be developed. 
Graduate students who work on this project will receive theoretical and practical training, and will be prepared for diverse careers in science and technology. In an effort to increase exposure of science and enhance diversity of participants, the Cornell group will work with the 4H organization to offer workshops aimed at exposing junior-high-school students to science careers.  

Technical Description

Lasers that generate ultrashort light pulses have had enormous impact in science and applications. The field of ultrafast science has been built on a foundation of short-pulse lasers based on a single transverse mode of a cavity, or optical fibers that support a single transverse mode. In fibers that support multiple transverse modes, wave propagation is inherently spatiotemporal. The generation of ultrashort light pulses in a fiber laser with many transverse modes was recently demonstrated for the first time.
A group from Cornell University will work to develop lasers and optical amplifiers with new capabilities, based on multimode optical fibers. In such a laser it is possible to control both the spatial and temporal degrees of freedom of the electromagnetic field. A particularly promising direction is scaling short-pulse fiber lasers to higher powers, which are always desired for applications. Numerical simulations of candidate laser designs will be performed. Lasers will be built and compared to the simulation results. Collaborators from the University of Central Florida will provide theoretical and computational support for this effort. The limits of performance will be investigated, and lasers will be designed for optimum performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Ultrashort light pulses (flashes of light that last less than 10-12 seconds ? a millionth of a millionth of a second) have found many applications in science.  These range from experiments that allow monitoring of chemical reactions as they occur to new techniques for microscopes that can see deeper into brain tissue, for example.  Such lasers would be very useful for application beyond scientific research, such as machining and surgery, if they could be made from optical fiber. The challenge is generating high-power short pulses in a fiber laser; pulses tend to get distorted as they propagate through a few meters of fiber with a small core. 

Fibers with larger core diameters would reduce the intensity of light in the fiber and consequently,  the effects that distort short pulses.  However, fibers with large cores do not produce the "pinpoint" beam we associate with lasers and that is so useful. A variety of intensity patterns (called modes) can exist in large-core fibers, and the beam that comes out of such a fiber is a complicated pattern of bright and dark regions. This project investigated the generation and propagation of ultrashort pulses in multimode fibers. Scientifically this is very interesting because the light wave propagation becomes 3-dimensional rather than 1-dimensional; a pulse of light changes its spatial and temporal profiles as it propagates in such a fiber. If this complicated propagation can be understood and controlled, it could be the basis of a new class of high-power lasers. 

 

Broader Impacts

Development of new lasers: Many applications benefit from lasers that supply higher power. In some cases increased power enables applications that would not be possible at lower power.  In other cases more power allows work to be done more efficiently (in manufacturing, for example). This project demonstrated new physics that is relevant to the design of high-power short-pulse lasers.

Tools for scientists and engineers: Numerical modeling is essential to the investigation of short-pulse generation and propagation.  Computer codes that were developed in the course of this project are available to the public.  

Development of human resources: This award provided partial funding support for three graduate students.  Two will complete their degrees by the end of 2023. One student has transitioned to a company that manufactures lasers, and the other has just begun to consider his next position.  The award also provided some support for two postdoctoral associates.  One joined the laser and optics industry after completing his appointment, and the other is still in the group. 

Intellectual property: Two patent applications have been filed, one on a new design for short-pulse lasers and one on a design for short-pulse amplifiers.
